content:
Your task is to create a concise running summary of actions and information results in the provided text, focusing on key and potentially important information to remember.

You will receive the current summary and the your latest actions. Combine them, adding relevant key information from the latest development in 1st person past tense and keeping the summary concise.

Summary So Far:
"""
{'role': 'system', 'content': 'This reminds you of these events from your past: \nI used the command "browse_website" to visit a link provided by the state government website in Michigan, which gave me information on identifying the different types of trees found in Michigan. The website listed over 75 species of trees, with pine, fir, spruce, and oak being some of the most common types. The soil in Michigan is sandy and is best for growing timber, potatoes, and strawberries.'}
"""

Latest Development:
"""
[{'role': 'your computer', 'content': "Command browse_website returned: Answer gathered from website: Michigan has over 75 native species of trees and many others planted from different parts of the world. The publication briefly describes 69 of the more common trees found in Michigan, including apple/crabapple, ash, aspen, basswood, beech, birch, boxelder, buckeye, butternut, catalpa, cedar, cherry, chestnut, cottonwood, dogwood, elm, fir, hackberry, hawthorn, hemlock, hickory, hophornbeam, Juneberry/serviceberry, Kentucky coffeetree, locust, maple, mulberry, musclewood/blue beech, oak, osage orange, pawpaw, pine, poplar, redbud, sassafras, spruce, sumac, sycamore, tamarack, tulip tree/yellow poplar, walnut, and willow. \n \n Links: ['\\n\\n\\n (https://msu.edu/)', 'MSU Extension (https://www.canr.msu.edu/outreach/about/home_page)', 'Natural Resources (https://www.canr.msu.edu/natural_resources/index)', 'Programs (https://www.canr.msu.edu/natural_resources/programs)', 'Experts (https://www.canr.msu.edu/natural_resources/experts)']"}, {'role': 'you', 'content': '{"command": {"name": "write_to_file", "args": {"filename": "michigan_trees.txt", "text": "The following is a list of the different types of trees found in Michigan, along with their characteristics:\\n\\n- Apple/Crabapple: Small to medium-sized tree with white or pink flowers in the spring and small, sour fruit in the fall.\\n- Ash: Large tree with compound leaves and winged seeds.\\n- Aspen: Medium-sized tree with smooth, white bark and round leaves that tremble in the wind.\\n- Basswood: Large tree with heart-shaped leaves and fragrant flowers in the summer.\\n- Beech: Large tree with smooth, light gray bark and oval-shaped leaves with pointed tips.\\n- Birch: Medium-sized tree with peeling, white bark and triangular-shaped leaves.\\n- Boxelder: Small to medium-sized tree with compound leaves and winged seeds.\\n- Buckeye: Medium-sized tree with large, palmate leaves and spiky fruit.\\n- Butternut: Medium-sized tree with compound leaves and rough, gray bark.\\n- Catalpa: Large tree with large, heart-shaped leaves and showy, white flowers in the summer.\\n- Cedar: Medium-sized tree with fragrant wood and scale-like leaves.\\n- Cherry: Medium-sized tree with white or pink flowers in the spring and small, red fruit in the summer.\\n- Chestnut: Large tree with large, toothed leaves and prickly fruit.\\n- Cottonwood: Large tree with heart-shaped leaves and cotton-like seeds.\\n- Dogwood: Small to medium-sized tree with showy, white or pink flowers in the spring.\\n- Elm: Large tree with rough, gray bark and oval-shaped leaves with pointed tips.\\n- Fir: Medium to large-sized tree with soft needles and cones that stand upright on the branches.\\n- Hackberry: Medium-sized tree with warty bark and small, purple fruit.\\n- Hawthorn: Small to medium-sized tree with showy, white or pink flowers in the spring and small, red fruit in the fall.\\n- Hemlock: Medium-sized tree with short, flat needles and cones that hang downward on the branches.\\n- Hickory: Large tree with compound leaves and large, edible nuts.\\n- Hophornbeam: Small to medium-sized tree with bark that resembles muscle tissue and small, nut-like fruit.\\n- Juneberry/Serviceberry: Small to medium-sized tree with showy, white flowers in the spring and small, edible fruit in the summer.\\n- Kentucky coffeetree: Large tree with large, compound leaves and large, brown seed pods.\\n- Locust: Medium-sized tree with compound leaves and showy, white flowers in the spring.\\n- Maple: Medium-sized tree with lobed leaves that turn vibrant colors in the fall.\\n- Mulberry: Small to medium-sized tree with heart-shaped leaves and edible fruit.\\n- Musclewood/Blue Beech: Small to medium-sized tree with smooth, gray bark that resembles muscle tissue.\\n- Oak: Large tree with lobed leaves and acorns.\\n- Osage Orange: Medium-sized tree with thorny branches and large, green fruit.\\n- Pawpaw: Small to medium-sized tree with large, tropical-looking leaves and edible fruit.\\n- Pine: Medium to large-sized tree with long needles and cones that are typically longer than they are wide.\\n- Poplar: Large tree with heart-shaped leaves and cotton-like seeds.\\n- Redbud: Small to medium-sized tree with showy, pink or purple flowers in the spring.\\n- Sassafras: Small to medium-sized tree with three different leaf shapes on the same tree.\\n- Spruce: Medium to large-sized tree with short needles and cones that hang downward on the branches.\\n- Sumac: Small to medium-sized tree with compound leaves and showy, red fruit in the fall.\\n- Sycamore: Large tree with peeling, patchy bark and large, lobed leaves.\\n- Tamarack: Medium-sized tree with short, soft needles that turn yellow in the fall.\\n- Tulip Tree/Yellow Poplar: Large tree with four-lobed leaves and yellow-green flowers in the spring.\\n- Walnut: Large tree with compound leaves and large, edible nuts.\\n- Willow: Medium-sized tree with long, narrow leaves and drooping branches."}}}'}]
"""
